text: It is a millionaire's house, big, sprawling, California style, with clipped lawns and gardens, on a hill above th now abandoned oil field which was the family's wealth. A small coupe drives up to the door and stops, and Philip Marlowe gets out. We just have time to establish him as h approaches the door -- a husky, self-confident man, well- dressed but not flashy.
lettered
as NORRIS opens the door. Norris is thin, silver-haired with a gentle intelligent face.
(holding the door) Good morning, sir.
I'm Philip Marlowe. General Sternwood sent for me.
(opens door, steps aside) Yes, Mr. Marlowe. Will you come in?
(entering) Thanks.
as Norris shuts the door, takes Marlowe's hat.
Will you sit here? I'll tell the General you have come.
Okay. Norris exits. Marlowe looks about, interested and curiou sees something, moves toward it.

as he stands before a portrait, examining it with curious interest. It is a portrait of General Sternwood, in regimentals, beneath crossed battle-torn cavalry pennons and a sabre. He is still staring at the portrait when at SOUND OFF, he turns and sees CARMEN STERNWOOD approaching She is about 20, in slacks, something sullen and hot abou her. She stops about 10 feet from him and stares at him, biting the thumb of her left hand.
Good morning.
(after a moment) You're not very tall are you?
I tried to be.
Not bad looking, though -- you probably know it.
Thanks. He goes to a chair and sits down. When he looks up, he sees Carmen approaching, still staring at him.
(approaching) What's your name?
Reilly -- Doghouse Reilly.
(beside the chair now) That's a funny name. Are you a prize fighter?
No. I'm a shamus.
A what?
A private detective.

You're cute. As she speaks, she sits suddenly on the arm of his chair. As she does so, Marlowe rises, shifts the chair in doing so, so that to her surprise, Carmen finds herself sitting in the chair itself. She stares up, surprised and then angrily, is about to speak again when they both see Norri He has just entered noiselessly, stands beside the chair. On Norris' face there is now a curious expression of grie sadness. Carmen glances up at him, rises quickly as if he had reprimanded her with words, and exits. Marlowe looks after her, thoughtful, a little grim.
The General will see you now.
(looking after Carmen) Who was that?
Miss Carmen Sternwood, sir.
You ought to wean her. She looks old enough.
Yes, sir. This way, if you please. They exit through French doors.

Garage at one side, beyond it a tremendous greenhouse. Norris is leading Marlowe along the path toward the green house. A chauffeur is washing a car before the garage. we establish him in passing -- a handsome, boyish-looking ma OWEN TAYLOR. Marlowe follows Norris on to the greenhouse, looking at t tremendous size of it as Norris opens the door and stands aside for Marlowe to enter.

Marlowe, following Norris between the crowding tendrils a branches. The place is oven-hot, damp with sweat, green with gloom. Marlowe is already reacting to it, is already mopping his face with his handkerchief.
(mopping neck, following Norris) Couldn't we have gone around this?
(over shoulder; walking on) The General sits in here, sir.

in a wheelchair in center of the greenhouse, in a cleared space about which the plants crowd and hover. The GENERAL is the man we saw in the portrait, though older, and obviously dying, so that only his fierce eyes seem to hav any life. Even in the terrific heat his body is wrapped i a traveling rug and a heavy bathrobe, his gnarled hands lying like dead gnarled twigs on the rug, his fierce eyes following as Norris leads Marlowe in.
(stopping) This is Mr. Marlowe, General. The General does not speak, only the fierce eyes stare at Marlowe as Norris pushes a wicker chair up behind Marlowe legs.
Brandy, Norris. (to Marlowe) How do you like your brandy, sir?
(sitting down) Just with brandy. Norris takes Marlowe's hat, exits.
I used to like mine with champagne. The champagne cold as Valley Forge and about three ponies of brandy under it. You may take your coat off, sir.
Thanks. He rises, removes his coat, takes out his handkerchief, hangs his coat on chair.
(watching him) It's too hot in here for any man who still has blood in his veins. Marlowe sits again, mops his face and neck.
(still watching him) You may smoke too. I can still enjoy the smell of it, anyway.
Thanks. He produces a Cigarette, lights it, blows smoke, Sternwoo nostrils moving as he sniffs the smoke. Norris enters, pushing a teawagon bearing decanter, siphon, initialed ice-bucket.
That man is already dead who must indulge his own vices by proxy. Norris wheels the wagon up, starts to prepare a drink.
(watching pettishly) Come, man. Pour a decent one.
(adding brandy) Yes, General.
(watching) But not too decent, Norris. I don't want to exchange places with it. Norris adds soda, hands glass to Marlowe.

(taking glass) Thanks. He sits back. Norris covers the ice-bucket with a napkin, exits. SOUND of DOOR CLOSING as Norris leaves the greenhouse. Marlowe raises the glass, sips. Sternwood watches him, licks his lips with longing pleasure and enjoyment. Marlowe lowers the glass.
Tell me about yourself, Mr. Marlowe. I suppose I have the right to ask.

There's not much to tell. I'm thirty-eight years old, went to college once. I can still speak English when there's any demand for it in my business. I worked for the District Attorney's office once. It was Bernie Ohls, his chief investigator, who sent me word you wanted to see me. I'm not married.
You didn't like working for Mr. Wilde?
I was fired for insubordination I seem to rate pretty high on that.
I always did, myself. Sir -- (he slides one hand under the rug on his knees) What do you know about my family, Mr. Marlowe?

(mopping ) oo. . You're a widower, a millionaire, two young daughters. One unmarried, the other married once but it didn't didn't take. Both now living with you and both -- (he breaks off; the General's fierce eyes watch him)
Go on.
Am I to swap you gossip for hospitality?
(sternly) You are to swap me your confidence for my own.
(shrugs) All right. Both pretty, and both pretty -- wild. What did you want to see me about?
I'm being blackmailed again.
__ (mopping) Again?
(draws his hand out from under the rug, holding a brown envelope) About a year ago I paid a man named Joe Brody five thousand dollars to let my younger daughter alone.
Ah.
What does that mean?
It means 'ah.' It never went through the D.A.'s office, or I'd have known it. Who handled that for you?
Shawn Regan did.
(alternating between the drink, the cigarette and the now sodden handkerchief with which he mops his face and neck) There must be some reason why Regan's not handling this one too. Am I to know it?
Shawn has left me.
I thought I hadn't seen him around lately.

Yes, he left about a month ago, without a word. That was what hurt. I had no claim on him, since I was only his employer. But I hoped we were more than that and that he would have said goodbye to me. You knew him too?
Yes. From the old days, when he was running rum from Mexico and I was on the other side, and now and then we swapped shots between drinks -- or drinks between shots, if you like that better.
My respects to you. Few men ever exchange more than one shot with Shawn Regan. He commanded a brigade in the Irish Republican Army, you know.
(moppin No, I didn't. But I knew he was a good man at whatever he did. Nobody was pleased better than me when I heard you had taken him on as your -- whatever he was here.

As my friend, my son almost. Many's the hour he would sit here with me, sweating like a pig, drinking the brandy I could no longer drink, telling me stories of the Irish revolution -- But enough of this. (he holds out the envelope) Here. And help yourself to the brandy. Marlowe takes the envelope, sits again, wipes his hands o his wet handkerchief, removes from the envelope a card an three clips of stiff paper.

-- in Marlowe's hand Mr. Arthur Gwynne Geiger Rare Books and Deluxe Editions Marlowe's hand turns the card over. On the back, in hand-printing. Dear Sir: In spite of the legal uncollectibility of the enclosed, which frankly are gambling debts, I assume you might wish them honored. Respectfully, A.G. Geiger.

Filled out in ink, dated: September 3 September 8 September 11 On demand I promise to pay to Arthur Gwynne Geiger on order the sum of One Thousand Dollars ($1,000.00) without interest. Value Received. Carmen Sternwood
Sternwood watching from wheelchair as Marlowe mixes himse a drink at the wagon, then turns toward chair.
(watching Marlowe) well?
(standing) Who's Arthur Gwynne Geiger?
I haven't the faintest idea.
Have you asked your daughter?  10.
I don't intend to. If I did she would suck her thumb and look coy.
Yeah. I met her in the hall. She did that at me. Then she tried to sit in my lap. Sternwood stares at him. After a moment Marlowe raises th glass, drinks, lowers it.
(harshly) well?
(stares at him a moment) Am I being polite, or can I say what I want?
Say it.
Do the two girls run around together?

I think not. They are alike only in their one corrupt blood. Vivian is spoiled, exacting, smart, ruthless. Carmen is still the child who likes to pull the wings off flies. I assume they have always had all the usual vices; whatever new ones of their own invention -- (again he makes the repressed convulsive movement, glares at Marlowe) well?
Pay him.
Why?  11.

It's cheaper. A little money against a lot of annoyance. The money you won't miss, and if your heart hasn't broken long before this time, whatever's behind these -- (indicates the notes on the chair) -- can't do it now.
Not my heart. No Sternwood ever had one. But there is my pride, which I at least, and I believe my older daughter still, both have.
Sure. A man named A.G. Geiger's just betting himself three thousand bucks on that pride. Who was this Joe Brody you paid the five thousand to?

I don't recall. Norris would know. My butler. I think he called himself a gambler. (hopefully) This may be an authentic gambling debt, after all. Marlowe looks at Sternwood for a moment. Then he half turns, sets the glass on the wagon and takes the napkin from around the ice bucket and mops himself with it. Sternwood watches him.
Do you think it is?
(after a second) No. Marlowe mops himself again with the napkin, puts it back the wagon, takes up his glass, drinks.
I guess you want me to take this Geiger off your back: that right?
Do you want to know anything, or do you just want to be rid of him?
Didn't you just tell me I no longer have any heart to be broken?

It may cost you a little -- besides my own twenty-five a day and expenses. Sternwood says nothing, merely makes a faint, impatient movement of his head or shoulders. Marlowe drains the glass, sets it back on the wagon.
When do I start?
At once. And now if you will excuse me -- But another brandy before you go?
(takes up papers from chair, then his coat) No thanks.

(presses bell plugged into chair arm) Then good morning. And good luck. He lies back in the chair, closes his eyes. Marlowe watches him a moment, then, his coat over his arm and sti mopping his neck, he turns and exits.

emerges, still carrying his coat, dripping wet, mopping with his sodden handkerchief, breathing the cool air, starts away. Before he reaches the house, Norris meets him, pauses two feet away, silver-haired, respectful, grave.
Mrs. Rutledge, the older daughter would like to see you before you leave, sir. And about the money: the General has instructed me to give you a check for whatever you require.  13. 13.
Instructed you how?
(blinks, stares, then smiles) Ah, I see, sir. I forgot you are a detective. By the way he rang the bell.
You write his checks.
I have that privilege.
(starts on) That ought to save you from a pauper's grave. I won't need any money now, thanks -- How did Mrs. Rutledge know I was here?
She saw you through the window. I was obliged to tell her who you were.
I don't like that.
Are you attempting to tell me my duties, sir?
No. Just having fun trying to guess what they are.
This way, sir.

The room is large, over-elaborate, feminine. VIVIAN reclines on a chaise-lounge, showing her legs to good advantage. She is beautiful, giving an impression of strong will and strong emotions, the dangerous unpredictable type.  14. She sips a drink, insolently at ease, watching Marlowe as he enters. Marlowe is still rumpled and sweating. He adopts her be-damned-to-you attitude, looks her over, and sits down unbidden, wiping his face and neck with his handkerchief.
So you're a private detective. I didn't know they existed except in books, or else they were little greedy men snooping around hotels. My, you're a mess, aren't you?
Yeah -- I'm not the orchid-bearing type.
This business of Dad's -- think you can handle it for him?
(sardonically) It doesn't look too tough.
Really. I would have thought a case like that took a little effort.
Not too much.
Well! what will your first step be?
The usual one.
I didn't know there was a usual one.
Oh, yes. It comes complete with diagrams on Page forty-seven of "How to be a Detective in Ten Easy Lessons", correspondence school textbook.
You must have read another one on how to be a comedian. I'm quite serious, Mr. Marlowe. My father is not well, and I want this case handled with the least possible worry to him.  15.
That's the way I'm going to handle it.
I see. No professional secrets. Marlowe doesn't answer. He's still admiring her legs. Vivian sets her glass down, looking him over coolly, as though he were something in a bottle.
How do you like Dad?
I liked him.
He liked Shawn. I suppose you know who Shawn is?
Yeah, I know.
You don't have to play poker with me. Dad wants to find him, doesn't he?
Do you?
Of course I do! It wasn't right for him to go off like that. Broke Dad's heart, although he won't say much about it. Or did he?
He mentioned it.
I don't see what there is to be cagey about. And I don't like your manners.

I'm not crazy about yours. I didn't ask to see you. And I don't mind your ritzing me, or drinking your lunch out of a bottle. I don't mind your showing me your legs. They're very swell legs and it's a pleasure to make their acquaintance. I don't mind if you don't like my manners. (MORE )

They're pretty bad. I grieve over them during the long winter evenings. But don't waste your time trying to cross-examine me. Vivian is really angry now. She swings her legs to the floor, and her anger is something sparkling and terrific.
People don't talk like that to me. Marlowe laughs at her softly. His eyes are warm and mocking. Vivian relaxes slowly, looking at him, and something besides fury comes into her own face.
Do you always think you can handle people like trained seals?
Just what is it you're afraid of? They watch each other, and Vivian's face closes against him like a door.
Dad didn't want to see you about Shawn at all.
Didn't he?
Get out. (as Marlowe rises and turns from her) Please... you could find Shawn if Dad wanted you to.
(still dead pan) When did he go?
A month back. He just drove away one afternoon without saying a word. They found his car in some private garage.
(her manner suddenly different, as though she has won her bout with him) Dad didn't tell you then.
He told me about Regan, yes. That's not what he wanted to see me about. Is that what you've been trying to get me to say?
I'm sure I don't care what you say.
(giving her a look she could chin herself on) You might change your mind about that some day. So long, Mrs. Rutledge. Vivian watches him as he goes out, with smoldering, puzzled eyes.
Marlowe comes down the hall, heading for the door. Norris appears with Marlowe's hat and hands it to him.
You made a mistake. Mrs. Rutledge didn't want to see me.
I'm sorry, sir. I make many mistakes. He opens the door. Marlowe pauses to look at the view.

Beyond the lawns and hedges of the Sternwood estate the ground falls away to barren fields with several old woode derricks, some of them still wearily pumping oil. The derricks are at a considerable distance from the house, b a man with binoculars could see any activity around them clearly enough. The sky is clouded; THUNDER SOUNDS distantly.  18.
How long those wells been pumping?

About thirty years. The General likes to take his field glasses sometimes and sit by the window and watch the walking-beams. They're like life, he says -- an endless seesaw, forever up and down and getting nowhere
They get oil. Black stuff, with a smell to it... worth dollars. He goes out, gets into his car and drives away. The SOUND of THUNDER follows him.

The typical reading room, with the usual characters hunch over books at the tables. Marlowe stands by the librarian's desk. A boy comes from the door to the stacks and hands the librarian a book. She looks at it.
Famous First Editions. (looking at Marlowe -- it is obvious that she feels he's not the type to be reading about first editions) This was the one you wanted?
(blandly, as he takes the book) I collect blondes, too -- in bottles. He walks over to a table and sits down, leaving the woman staring after him.  19. 20. 19.

Sign on window: "RARE EDITIONS" etc. Marlowe walks up and pauses to assure himself that it's the right place. The store front is narrow. Discreet gold lettering on the plate glass repeats the legend on Geiger's card:

Rare Books and Deluxe Editions The windows are blanked off with Chinese screens, fronted by large Oriental urns. Marlowe puts on a pair of horn- rimmed sun glasses, adjusts his hat to a less rakish angle, and enters.

The room is small, din, expensively underfurnished with leather chairs, smoking stands, and a small psuedo- Oriental desk. A few sets of tooled leather binds on narrow tables, others in glass cases. AGNES, a hard-looking, expensive blonde in a tight black dress, rises from behind the desk as Marlowe approaches and moves to greet him. Her manner is professionally distant, her accent betrays her phony veneer.
Can I be of any assistance?
Would you happen to have a Ben Hur 1860?
(hanging on hard to her composure, seeing that she's going to have trouble with Marlowe) A first edition?
No. Third -- the one with the erratum on page one-sixteen.
I'm afraid not -- at the moment.  20.
How about a Chevalier Audubon -- the full set of course?
(with a frozen smile) Uh -- not at the moment.
(politely) You do sell books?
(dropping the act, pointing to the display books) What do those look like -- grapefruit?
They look like books from here, anyway. Maybe I'd better talk to Mr. Geiger.

He's not in at the moment. Marlowe glances up as a man enters the store; a middle- aged, important-looking person who has an incongruously furtive and nervous manner. He looks quickly at Marlowe, then at Agnes, who gives him an almost imperceptible warning nod. Marlowe remains blandly unaware of the byplay, all his attention apparently on the cigarette he' lighting. The man walks quickly to the rear of the store. Agnes pushes a button on the desk. A door in the back wall open on a buzzer lock. The man darts through it like a rabbit.
(to Marlowe) I said Mr. Geiger is not in.
I heard you. I'll wait for him.

He won't be back until very late. At this point the furtive man comes out of the rear part the store and leaves hurriedly, looking at neither Agnes nor Marlowe. His face is lined and haggard. Marlowe is interested.  21. 21.
(watching the man out) He must have got hold of the wrong title. (to Agnes) Well, guess I'd better blow. I'm already late now for my lecture on Argentine cera-micks. (mispronouncing the word)
(icily, correcting him) The word is cerAMics. And they ain't Argentine: they're Egyptian.
You did sell a book once, didn't you? Well, even the Argentine's a little too far for me today. Guess I'll just stick to the public library -- or I might try that book store across the street.
(freezing) Do so. Agnes stares viciously at his back until he is out. Then she goes to the door at the rear, knocks and goes through

He walks across the boulevard, turns into a small bookstore, the second-hand variety, cluttered and dingy. Several nondescript people browse among the tables. At th rear a small, dark, shrewd-faced woman sits reading at a desk -- apparently she is the proprietor. Marlowe approaches her, and she looks up blank-faced from her boo
Would you do me a very small favor?
I don't know. What is it?
You know Geiger's store across the street?
I think I may have passed it.
You know Geiger by sight?  The woman open it. The woman 22.
I should think it would be easy enough to go to his store and ask to see him.
I don't want to see him that close, just yet. (as he gets no response) Know anything about rare books?
You could try me.
Would you have a Ben Hur, 1860, Third Edition, with the duplicated line on page one-sixteen? pulls a fat volume in front of her, starts to
...or a Chevalier Audubon 1840...? stops, closes the book.
Nobody would. There isn't one.
Right. (as the woman gives him a puzzled stare) The girl in Geiger's store didn't know that.
I see. You begin to interest me -- vaguely.
I'm a private dick on a case. Perhaps I ask too much. (leaning forward to hold a match for her cigarette) It didn't seem much to me somehow.  22. 23.

(after a pause) In his early forties, medium height, fattish, soft all over, a Charlie Chan moustache. Well dressed, goes without a hat, affects a knowledge of antiques and hasn't any. Oh yes, his left eye is glass.
You'd make a good cop.
(returning to her reading) Only if he wore smoked glasses.

(laughing softly -- pulling a flat pint from his hip pocket) I shouldn't think you'd have to work too hard to start anything smoking. He shakes the bottle up and down, invitingly. She looks u at him, searchingly, then smiles slowly.
It's going to rain, soon.

I'd rather get wet in here. She pulls open a drawer and stands two small glasses on the desk. Marlowe smiles, and starts pouring. Through the window behind him the front of Geiger's store can be seen.

It is raining hard outside. The proprietress is a little tight, quite relaxed, and slightly philosophical, leaning against Marlowe, who sits on a stack of Britannicas besid her, watching the window. The proprietress picks up the bottle, which is now empty, shakes it forlornly, and sets it down again.
A couple of hours, an empty bottle, and so long, pal. That's life.  24.
But it was a nice two hours.
(sighing) Uh-huh. (looking toward the window) There's Geiger's car driving up.
(over above action) Who's the other guy?
Damon -- or Pythias. I don't know. Geiger's shadow, anyway. Name's Carol Lundgren. Marlowe has risen, is now in a hurry to follow Geiger.
So long, pal.
If you ever want to buy a book...
A Ben Bur eighteen-sixty...
(sighing) With duplications... So long.
Wet with rain:

A narrow street with a high bank on one side and a scattering of cabinlike houses built down the slope on th other side, so that their roofs are not much above street level. They are masked by hedges and shrubs. Sodden trees line the dark road.  25. 26. 27. 28. 25. The headlights of a car appear. Geiger's coupe drives up and stops in front of the garage of a small house almost completely hidden by a square box hedge. Geiger gets out, opens an umbrella, and vanishes behind the hedge. Almost immediately Marlowe's car appears, continuing slowly past Geiger's house. It turns, stops under a tree. The lights go out.
Marlowe yawns, gets a bottle out of the dash compartment, shakes it reflectively.
Another hour, another bottle -- another dame? He uncaps the bottle, salutes an unseen person wryly, drinks, then lights a cigarette and settles down to wait.

A dark convertible stops in front of Geiger's house. The lights go out. A small slim woman in a vagabond hat and raincoat gets out. She pauses, looking around -- we see her face dimly. It is CARMEN STERNWOOD. She vanishes behind the hedge. The DOORBELL RINGS faintly, the door opens and closes.
Marlowe looks offscene after Carmen, with an unpleasant grin.
Yeah -- another dame. His expression indicates that things may pick up shortly. He looks at his watch -- the CAMERA MOVES IN to feature t watch -- the hands standing at 6:35.
The hands now indicate: 7:20  29. 30. 31. 32. 33. 34. 26.

SHOOTING obliquely across Marlowe's shoulder, showing the street and particularly Geiger's house through the rain- streaked windscreen. Suddenly a hard white flash of light shoots out of Geiger's house like s flash of lightning. Close on its heels comes a woman's thin half-pleasurable scream. Marlowe is out of the car and on his way.

Marlowe rounds the hedge on the run. There is a wooden footbridge bridging the gap between the bank and the fron door. He covers this in two jumps and stops at the front door. The knocker is in the shape of a lion's head, and ring in its mouth. Marlowe puts his hand on it, and as he does, three SHOTS SOUND from inside. Marlowe freezes. From inside we HEAR a sighing groan and the thud of a falling body, then footsteps going away. Marlowe looks over the railing of the bridge, but there's no way around to the back. He stands still, listening. Light shows from the house, behind draperies. From offscene at some distance, we HEAR someone running down steps.
On a man's feet, running with hysterical speed down the w treads. We follow them across muddy ground, apparently a dirt road surface, to a car.
As a car starts and roars away with clashing gears. Almos before it is out of sight a second car pulls out from und shrouding trees and follows it.

The SOUND of the two cars is still audible, fading into distance. Marlowe listens to it. When everything is quiet again he tries the front door, finds it locked. French windows flank the door just out of reach beyond the raili of the bridge. Marlowe swings out over the railing, kicks in the right-hand window, and pulls himself over the sill

As Marlowe comes in through the window. The room is wide, low-beamed ceiling, brown plaster walls with strips of Chinese embroidery and Oriental prints on them. Low bookshelves, a desk, thick rug floor cushions, low divans -- an exotic messy atmosphere.  27. On a low dais at one end of the room is a carved teakwood chair, a massive thing in which Carmen Sternwood sits, rigidly erect, in the pose of an Egyptian goddess. She wears a man's large silk dressing gown -- it doesn't pretend to fit her and gives the impression of having bee thrown hurriedly around her by someone other than herself Carmen's eyes have a queer fixed stare. She pays no attention to Marlowe. She looks as if, in her mind, she i doing something very important and doing it well. She seems pleased about it, her lips curved to a smile. She laughs from time to time -- softly, secretly. Opposite her, Geiger lies on the floor in front of a thin like a totem pole. The eye of the totem is a camera lens; it focuses on the chair where Carmen sits. A blackened flash bulb is clipped to the totem beside it. Geiger is dressed in semi-oriental fashion. His embroidered coat is soaked with blood. He is obviously dead. Marlowe takes all this in, sniffs the air. It is heavy with something unpleasant. He crosses to a small lacquer table bearing a flagon of dark liquid and two glasses. Marlowe sniffs the flagon, makes a grimace of disgust. Carmen's clothes are wadded up on the divan. Marlowe pick up her coat and shoes and goes to her.

Hello. Remember me. She doesn't seem to see him. The soft, secret laughter is his only answer. He goes closer, and deliberately slaps her face. This gets a reaction -- he slaps her again, without emotion, but hard. Carmen comes to, slightly, giving him a sly, mad smile.
You're higher than a kite. Come on, let's be nice. Let's get dressed, Carmen. He puts her shoes on.
(giggling) You tickle.

Yeah, you tickle me, too. Marlowe pulls her to her feet and puts her coat on, tryin not to dislodge the dressing gown. She falls against him, very happy about it all, apparently about to pass out. Marlowe is not happy.  35. 36. 28.
Let's take a walk.
(thickly, half conscious) You're cute.
Sure, sure. So's your boyfriend. Want to look at him? He walks the staggering girl over to Geiger's body. It is hard work -- and Carmen is not impressed.
(as before) He's cute.

Cute. Yeah. Let's walk. He walks her back and forth across the room a couple of times -- LOW CAMERA FEATURING the dead man as their legs pass in front of him. Then she passes out in his arms, still convinced that everything is cute. He spreads her out on the divan, unconsciously wiping his hands on his coat as though he has touched something dirty. Then he returns to the totem and Geiger's body. He examines the concealed camera. The plateholder is gone. He rolls Geiger's body over enough to see under it. No plateholder. He frowns thoughtfully at the girl... then goes into the rear of the house.

Marlowe passes quickly through the bath and kitchen, pausing to try the locked kitchen door and to examine a window which had been jimmied open. The scars show plainl on the wood, the rain blowing in unheeded. Marlowe then goes to the bedroom, which is in keeping with the living room. He glances briefly through the closet, with a man's clothes in it, then picks up a keyholder from the dressin table, where it has been placed along with other contents of Geiger's pockets -- money, handkerchief, etc.
Marlowe returns and unlocks the desk. In one drawer he finds a locked steel box, which he opens with Geiger's keys. He takes from it a leather book.  37. 38. 39. 40. 29.
He leafs through the pages slowly, showing an index and writing in code, in the same slanted printing as on the cards General Sternwood gave him.

Marlowe places the book in his pocket, wipes his fingerprints carefully from the box, replaces it end lock the desk. He pockets the keys, turns off the lamps and th gas logs in the fireplace, makes a wadded bundle of Carmen's clothes, jams her hat on her head and picks her up, holding her clothes awkwardly in one hand. On the way out he pushes down the light switch by the door, and kick the door shut behind him.
as Marlowe carries the sleeping girl out to her car.

Marlowe has just rung the doorbell. In the drive behind him stands Carmen's Packard. The door opens. Norris appears in it, recognizes Marlowe, looks swiftly past him and recognizes the car also. Then he looks at Marlowe again -- the same quiet, grave face with its expression of grief and sadness which the sight of the ca brought into it. His voice though is quiet and calm.
Good evening, sir.
(rapidly) Mrs. Rutledge in?
No, sir.
The General?
He's asleep.
Good. Where's Mrs. Rutledge's maid?  41. 30.
Mathilda? She's here.

Better get her down here. This job needs a woman's touch. Take a look inside the car. But Norris does not move, only his eyes go again to the waiting car and return, his face still grave, only the grief a little sharper behind it.
(quickly) She's all right?
Sure. She's okay. Just get that maid. Mathilda can do all right for her.
We all try to do our best for her. I'll call Mathilda at once.
(turning) Then I'll leave it with you. Goodnight.
May I call you a cab, sir?
(pauses) No. In fact, I'm not here. You haven't even seen me tonight -- see?
Yes, sir. Marlowe turns on, fast, walking down the drive in the rai

Marlowe, a shadowy figure, enters, closes door behind him crosses the room to a lamp, turns the switch. Marlowe is quite wet, indicating that he has walked back from Sternwood's.  42. 43. 44. 31. He stands with his hand still on the light switch, looks about the room, crosses to another tamp, puts it on, is about to turn away when he stops dead, reacts as he looks at the totem pole and at the floor beneath it where Geiger's body had lain. The body is gone. Marlowe crosses the room, wasting no time, determined. He passes through door to bedroom, snap light on beyond it, after a moment the light beyond the door snaps off and Marlowe re-enters living room. He has not found the body. He stands for a moment, thinking, the he goes and kneels so that he can squint along the surfac of the thick rug. He sees in the nap the marks where Geiger's heels were dragged along it, across the room toward the front door. He rises at last, thoughtful, slowly takes out a cigarette and lights it, drops match into ashtray, stops, takes up the dead match and puts it into his pocket. Then he takes out his handkerchief, goes and wipes off th bedroom doorknob, goes to the first lamp, turns it out an wipes it off, leaving room in darkness and himself a shad which can be barely seen in the act of wiping off that button. Then he crosses the room.
Marlowe as he closes and locks it, wipes off knob, pocket keys, turns.

Marlowe, sitting at a table, the code book which he found at Geiger's open before him, a highball at his hand as he tries to work out the code. He cannot solve it. His hand reaches for the highball glass.

Marlowe, in bed, wakes reluctantly as LOUD KNOCKING on th apartment door penetrates his slumber. He crawls out of bed, obviously the worse for a hangover, pulls ona dressing gown as he staggers sleepily toward the next roo
(as the KNOCKING continues) All right, all right. Keep your pants on...  45. 32.

as Marlowe opens it to admit BERNIE OHLS, a dapper slightly flashy man, whose clothes are expensive and alwa a little wrong. His face is dapper and deceiving since it is actually the face of a man who has been in close place in the course of his duty, has killed several lawbreakers at times when he was outnumbered and they thought he was covered and helpless until too late. He is pleasant and affable to all, respects courage, loves no man.
Well Bernie. Don't you ever go to bed?
(entering -- surveying Marlowe) Boy, what a beautiful hangover! Tut, tut -- man your age, out on the town all night...
I got it right here.
(sitting) That's even worse.
All right -- what is it?
Does it have to be something?
Look, Bernie, when somebody from the Homicide Squad comes over to help...
You're working for the Sternwoods, aren't you?
(warily) Yeah.
Done anything for ‘em yet?
How could I do anything yesterday in all that rain?  46. 33.
(laughing) Okay -- They seem to be a family that things happen to. A big Buick belonging to one of them is washing around in the surf off Lido fish pier. Oh yea, I almost forgot. There's a guy in it.
(flatly, after a pause) Regan?
Who? Oh, you mean that Irish ex-legger old Sternwood hired to do his drinking for him. What would he be doing down there? He watches Marlowe's face narrowly -- it tells him nothin
What would anybody be doing down there?
That's what I'm going to Lido to find out. Want to come?
Thanks, Bernie. Yeah, be with you in ten minutes. He starts out, already pulling off his dressing gown. Ohls looks after him, frowning.
Ohls is driving. It is an official car, now and then Ohls sounds the siren.
It ain't Regan. I checked up. Regan's a big guy, tall as you and a shade heavier. This is a young kid. (he SOUNDS SIREN -- the car is going fast) What made you think it was Regan?  34.
Who is it? Don't they know yet?
Now, now. Behave. What made Regan skip out? Or ain't you interested in that either?
Why should I be?
That wasn't what old Sternwood wanted you for, then?
Can't a guy quit a job anymore without notifying the District Attorney?
When an ex-bootlegger gets himself hired into a job where all he's got to do is sit in a greenhouse and drink a millionaire's brandy, when he throws that job up --
I'm not looking for Regan.
Okay, keep buttoned, kid.
General Sternwood told you to send me out to see him. But he never told me I was to report --
I said, keep it buttoned, didn't I? (SOUNDS SIREN)
After all, you got to eat too -- even if I don't know why.
Sometimes I don't know either. Ohls SOUNDS the SIREN AGAIN. The car speeds on.  47. 48. 35.

A faded stucco arch, the sea beyond it, the pier stretchi away as Ohls' car stops before the entrance and Ohls and Marlowe get out. Beside the arch are parked a police car and several police motorcycles. The long pier, railed wit white two-by-fours, runs out over the water. There are several private cars parked along the road, a crowd of people is gathered at the far end of the pier as a motorcycle officer, stationed beneath the arch, is holdin back another crowd as Ohls and Marlowe come up. Ohls show the officer his badge.
(to guard) Medical examiner come yet?
(checks pass, waves them on) Beat you by 15 minutes. He's examining the guy now probably.
(pockets his pass) Oh, he is, huh? Didn't you guys ever hear of the D.A.'s office?
Keep your shirt on. There's a deputy in charge. Ohls, followed by Marlowe, passes onto the pier.

A shattered gap in the railing at the end of the pier sho where the car crashed through. Another crowd of people held back by other policemen, gather along the broken railing in b.g. Beyond them, moored to the end of the pier, lies a flat barge with wheelhouse and derrick. As Ohls and Marlowe approach, the police herd the crowd back and four men come up from the barge, carrying a sheet-covered stretcher and carry it on across the SHOT - the crowd gaping after it. As the bearers are about to pass, Ohls stops them.
Wait a minute. The bearers stop. Ohls turns the sheet back, looks at the dead man's face.  49. 36.
(over his shoulder to Marlowe) Want a look? Marlowe looks at the face for a moment. Ohls drops the sheet back.
(to bearers) All right. Beat it. The bearers go on. Ohls and Marlowe approach the barge, the crowd gawking about them, after the stretcher, the policemen shoving among them.
(to crowd) That's all now. Go on.

head_text.subj: DECK OF BARGE MOORED TO THE END OF THE PIER

text: On it sits the car which has been lifted from the water. It is the same black sedan which Marlowe saw the chauffeu washing yesterday in Sternwood's garage -- bent and stain with water. In front of the car are gathered Ohls, Marlowe, a uniformed deputy, two plainclothesmen and the Medical Examiner who has just finished repacking his smal black bag.
(to deputy) What's the story?

You can see most of it from here. Went through the rail yonder. Must have hit it pretty hard. The rain stopped down here about nine P.M. The broken ends of the rails are dry inside. That would put it about nine-thirty last night.
Drunk, huh?

Then he must have been that guy you hear about that always drives better drunk. He plowed an awful straight furrow down that pier, right to the end of it. Then he hit the railing right square head-on -- hard and clean -- or he wouldn't have gone through it.  50. They EXT. They hang 37.
All right. Suicide then.
The hand-throttle was set half-way down. Something had hit him a pretty hard lick across the left temple.
(to Medical Examiner ) All right, Doc. Let's have it.
His neck was broken.
What made the bruise? Steering-wheel?
It was made by something covered. The wound had already bled under the skin while he was still alive.
A blackjack? all turn and glance at Marlowe.
(after a moment) I'd forgotten about you. Let's go back to town.
are walking back toward their car. A few people still around, staring at the barge.
So you recognized him.
Yeah. Sternwood's chauffeur. I saw him washing that same car yesterday.
So that was what old Sternwood wanted with you.
Look, I don't even know his name --  51. 38.

I do. His name's Owen Taylor About a year or so back he run Sternwood's daughter, the hotcha one, off to Yuma. The older sister run after them and brought the girl back and had Taylor thrown into the icebox. Then the next day she comes down and begs the kid off -- said the kid meant to marry the sister only the sister can't see it. So they let the kid go, and darned if the Sternwoods don't have him come back to work, same as if nothing had happened.
And now somebody'll have to go see them about this.
Yep. That's me, probably.
Leave the old man out of it, if you can. He's got enough troubles already besides being sick.
Regan, huh?
I don't know anything about Regan. I told you that.
Then what are you doing in this?
I'm not looking for Regan. I can tell you that much.
(dryly) . . Yeah. I heard you the first time.
Marlowe enters, wearing the dark glasses as before, and a before, Agnes rises from behind the desk. She is not happ to see Marlowe.  39.
(cheerily) Hello -- I'm back again. Mr. Geiger in?
I'm afraid not. No. Marlowe glances around to make sure they're alone, then removes the glasses and moves close to Agnes.
It was just a stall about those first editions. I got something to sell. Something Geiger's wanted for a long time.
Oh -- I see. Well -- you might come back tomorrow. I think...
Drop the veil, sister. I'm in the business too. Agnes stares at him, scared stiff, not knowing how to get rid of him.
(impatiently) I haven't got forever. Is he sick? I could go up to the house

(frantically) No, that wouldn't do any good -- he's out of town. Couldn't you tomorrow? -- Marlowe glances up sharply as Carol Lundgren, the dark handsome boy in the leather jacket, opens the door in the rear wall. Behind him, through the open door, we see the back room, littered with the papers and boxes of hurried packing, and a gaunt, hard-looking man with a certain animal attractiveness in the midst of it, cramming folios and stacks of large-sized envelopes into the packing boxe Carol is obviously strained and under tension, looking as though he has not slept.

(desperately) Agnes, you've got to --  52. 53. 40. He becomes aware of Marlowe, shuts up abruptly, and slams the door. From the partition his voice rises, sharp but unintelligible, answered by a heavier, man's voice -- no words come through, but the implication is clearly that Carol shall shut up and get out. A door slams violently, then there is silence. Marlowe, ignoring this byplay, and the stricken look on Agnes' face, puts on his glasses and touches his hat.
Tomorrow, then. Early.
Yes, early. Before Marlowe has quite left the shop she darts back through the rear door.
As he walks rapidly along the Boulevard to a taxi standin at the curb. A smart, competent-appearing girl sits reading a pulp magazine behind the wheel.
Marlowe sticks his head in, does a take, and relaxes.
(disgustedly) I would have to pick a girl at this point.
(giving him a cold stare) Anything you want, bud, I can give you.
(grinning) And with both fists, too, I'll bet. Tail job?
Cop?
Private.
(laying aside the magazine) Hop in. Marlowe looks down at the magazine.  54. 55. 56. 57. 58. 59. 60. 41.
It is a copy of TWO-GUN DETECTIVE TALES, with a lurid cov of gunmen and a gory corpse.
(grinning) Okay, kid. Take it. He gets in quickly.

(slapping down the flag) I got it. EXT. HOLLYWOOD STREET - CAB IN F.G. A light panel pickup job comes out of an alley and turns down the street. The gaunt, hard-looking man is driving. Marlowe leans forward and gives the cabby the high sign. The cab pulls out to follow.

A section of Randall Place, featuring an apartment buildi with a basement garage. An awning stretches out over the sidewalk -- lettering along the awning's side reads, RANDALL ARMS. The panel truck drives past the entrance an turns into the basement garage. Some distance behind it w see the cab pull into the curb. Marlowe gets out and walk toward the RANDALL ARMS.

The door stands open onto a small foyer, without desk or switchboard. A panel of gilt mailboxes is let into one wall of the entrance. Marlowe, after a glance inside, examines the names under the mail drops. One in particula catches his eye.
The name JOE BRODY is typewritten on the card.  61. 62. 63. 64. 65. 66. 42.
Marlowe taps the card, then gives the foyer one more Meaning look, turns.
As Marlowe returns to it. He speaks to the girl, who nods and drives away with him.
as the cab pulls into the curb in front of a non-descript office building. Marlowe gets out and leans in to pay the driver.
(handing her a bill) Nice going, kid. Buy yourself an orchid.
Thanks. You can take my number in case you have any more jobs you want done right. (indicating the serial number on her driver's cap) I mean this number.
What number did you think I thought you meant? The Cabby flustered clashes the gears savagely, shoots th cab away. Marlowe tips his hat to her and enters the building as she drives away.
Marlowe opens the door, which has Philip Marlowe in gilt letters on the upper glass.

A small room, cheaply furnished, with a closed door in on wall. Vivian sits waiting for him, beautifully but simply dressed, quite at ease. She seems in a better humor this Morning, smiling at the surprised Marlowe.  43.
Well, you DO exist, after all. I'd begun to think I dreamed you out of a bottle of bad gin. (with underlying hint of seriousness) I've been trying to get you on the phone all morning.
You can insult me just as well face to face. I don't bite -- much.
(apologetically) I was rather rude.
(smiling) An apology from a Sternwood? (unlocking the connecting door, holding it for her) Come into my boudoir.
Like the waiting room, it's shabby and not large. The usual desk, chairs, and filing cabinets.
(sitting) You don't put on much of a front.
You can't make much money at this trade, if you're honest. If you have a front, you're making money or expect to.
Oh -- are you honest?
Painfully.
(taking out a cigarette) How did you get into this slimy business, then?

(giving her a look as he lights it for her) Because people like you pay good money to have the slime cleaned up. 44. She looks away from him, angry hut not able to say anything. Marlowe sits down behind the desk.
What did you want to see me about? Taylor?
(softly) Poor Owen. So you know about that.
A D.A.'s man took me down to Lido. Turned out he knew more about it than I did. He knew Owen Taylor wanted to marry your sister -- once.

(quietly) Perhaps it wouldn't have been a bad idea. He was in love with her. We don't find much of that in our circle... (changing her tone) But I didn't come to see you about Owen. Do you feel yet that you can tell me what my father wants you to do?
Not without his permission.
Was it about Carmen?
I can't even say that. Vivian watches him for a moment, then gives in. She takes a thick white envelope from her bag and tosses it on the desk.
You'd better look at this anyway. Marlowe examines the envelope.  45.
A messenger brought it this morning.

Eight-thirty-five it says -- for you or your father. He opens the envelope, takes out a medium-sized photograp We do not see the subject of the picture, but Marlowe's reaction is significant. He whistles softly.
So that's what Carmen looks like! (to Vivian) How much do they want for this?
Five thousand -- for the negative and the rest of the prints. The deal has to be closed tonight, or they give the picture to some scandal sheet.
The demand came how?
A woman telephoned me, shortly after this thing was delivered.
There's nothing in the scandal sheet angle. Juries convict on that racket without leaving the box. what else is there?
Does there have to be something else? Marlowe nods -- his face is uncompromising.
(giving in again) The woman said there was a police jam connected with it, and I'd better lay it on the line fast or I'd be talking to my little sister through a wire screen.
(deadpan, nodding) What kind of a jam?
I don't know.  46.
Where's Carmen now?
She's at home -- still in bed, I think. She was sick last night.
She go out at all?
The servants say she didn't. I was up at Las Olindas across the State line playing roulette at Eddie Mars' Cypress Club. I lost my shirt. (taking another cigarette -- laughing wryly)
(getting up to hold the match for her) So you like roulette. You would.
Yes, the Sternwoods all like losing games. The Sternwoods can afford to. The Sternwoods have money. (bitterly) All it's bought them is a raincheck.
What was Owen doing with your car last night?
Nobody knows. He took it without permission. Do you think...?
He knew about this photo? (shrugging) I don't rule him out... Can you get five thousand in cash right away?
I can borrow it -- probably from Eddie Mars. (sardonically) There's a bond between us, you see. Shawn Regan ran away with Eddie's blonde wife.  47.
(turning away -- leaving a pause) You may need the money ina hurry.
How about telling the police?
You know better than that. The police might turn up something they couldn't sit on -- and then where would the Sternwoods be? (after a pause) How was it left?
The woman said she'd call me back with instructions at five.
Okay -- call me here as soon as you've heard from her.
Can you do anything?
I think so. But I can't tell you how -- or why.
I like you. You believe in miracles.
(laughing) I believe in people believing they're smarter than they are -- if that's a miracle. Have a drink? He reaches down into the desk drawer.

I'll have two drinks. Marlowe grins at her. He comes up with a bottle and two glasses, fills them, and takes one to her. They salute, start to drink and find that their eyes have met over the glass rims and refuse to come apart. Vivian breaks it, no because she is shy or coy, but because suddenly there is sadness in her face. Her gaze drops briefly, then returns to Marlowe, clear, steady, and sad.  48.
You're a lot like Shawn Regan. Marlowe looks at her, almost with tenderness and understanding.
You want to tell me now or later?
What?
What you're so anxious to find out.
It couldn't be -- you.
Let's do one thing at a time.
(rising) I think we've done enough for one day...
(gently) Want that other drink?
(going toward door) No... Marlowe sets his glass down on the desk and picks up the envelope.

You forgot this. She turns by the door as he approaches, holding out her hand for the envelope. Marlowe gives it to her, but doesn't let go of it. They are not thinking about the envelope. Slowly he bends to her -- she leans back against the wall, her lips parte her eyes soft, misted with tears. Marlowe's mouth covers hers. Presently they break -- Vivian puts her hand on Marlowe's cheek.  68. 69. 49.
(softly) Your face is like Shawn's too -- clean and thin, with hard bones under it... She turns, neither slowly nor fast, away from him, opens the door, and goes out.

Parked unobtrusively under some trees a reasonable distan from Geiger's house. Marlowe sits patiently, waiting, his hat pushed to the back of his head, his collar loosened, smoking quietly. Presently, in b.g. in front of Geiger's house, Carmen Sternwood appears furtively around the far end of the hedge, and goes quickly in through the gap leading to the front door. Marlowe reacts, then gets out, to follow her.

standing in an attitude of terror, her back pressed again the wall beside the front door to Geiger's house, staring at Marlowe as he enters. She raises one hand and clenches her teeth on her thumb, staring at him. The terror fades little as she recognizes him. She wears coat, hat, veil, etc.
Remember me now, don't you? Doghouse Reilly, the man that didn't grow very tall. Remember?
(making an effort to seem natural) Is this your doghouse?
Sure. Let's go inside, huh?
(shrinking, cringing) Inside?
You wanted to get in, didn't you? He pushes her away, unlocks the door, pushes it inward.  70. 50.
In with you. He shoves Carmen in ahead of him, follows.

Carmen standing, looking about the room, as Marlowe shuts the door and stands looking at Carmen. She feels him watching her, smiles at him. He doesn't answer it. The smile fades. Marlowe takes out pack of cigarettes, offers it. She shakes her head dumbly, staring at him. He lights a cigarette.
How much do you remember about last night?
Remember what? I was sick last night. I was home.

Sure you were. I mean, before you went hone. In that chair yonder -- on that orange shawl while they were taking pictures. Quit stalling. (staring at him, she starts to put her thumb in her mouth again) And stop biting your thumb too.
You -- were the one?
Me. How much do you remember?
Are you the police?
No. I'ma friend of your father's. (a moment ) Who killed him?
(faintly) Who else... knows?  51.
About Geiger? Not the police, or they'd be camping here. (a moment ) Maybe Joe Brody.
Joe Brody? Who's he?
Sure. Not Steve Brody: Joe Brody. Did Joe kill him?
Kill who?
Look sister. I don't know how much trouble you are accustomed to, but I hope you've had plenty of practice dodging it.
(nods her head) Yes. Joe did it.
Why? (she watches him out of the corners of her eyes, biting her thumb; he draws on cigarette, expels) Seen much of him lately?
No! TI hate him!
So you're all ready to tell the cops he did it, huh? (quickly, as she stares at him) That is, if we can just get rid of that photograph Geiger made last night.
Photograph? What photograph?  She turns She gives 52.
(drags at cigarette, expels smoke) Just like last night. What a scream we are. Sternwood and Reilly, two stooges in search of a comedian.
Your name isn't Reilly. It's Marlowe. Vivian told me.

So you are beginning to remember. And you came back to look for the photograph, but you couldn't get into the house. (she stares at him) The photo's gone. I looked for it last night. Brody took it with him.
I've got to go home now.
Sure. But I wouldn't tell the police about Brody yet. Don't even tell a soul you were ever here -- either last night, or today. Net even Vivian. Leave it to Doghouse Reilly. Where's your car?
On the back street, where nobody would see it. to go out as he turns to follow.
You're not going to tell anybody we were here, are you?

(gives him a swooning look) It depends. I never tell on people who are nice to me. him a languishing, swooning, inviting look, so that her attitude is a caricature of what her more brilliant and vivid sister's might be. Marlowe grasps her arm almost savagely, turns her toward the door.

Come on. Get out of here --  53. He stops; they both react as FEET SOUND beyond the doer approaching, they pause dead as the BELL RINGS. While the stand staring at each other, Carmen drooling almost with terror, the BELL RINGS AGAIN, ceases, then SOUND of KEY a the lock and a moment later the door opens and EDDIE MARS enters quickly and then stops dead, staring at them. He i a handsome, hard, horsy-looking man in beautiful, restrained, expensive clothes, who stands staring at them with complete composure for a moment. Then he looks at Carmen, shuts the door, takes his hat off.
Excuse the casual entrance. The bell didn't answer. Is Mr. Geiger around?
No. We don't knew just where he is. We found the doer open and stepped in.
I see. Friends of his?
Just business. We dropped in for a book. Mars stares hard at Marlowe, who stares just as hard back.

But we missed him. (takes Carmen's arm, pushes her toward door to pass Mars) So we'll trot along. As Marlowe is about to shoulder Mars aside to pass, Mars himself steps aside until Carmen has passed him, then he moves in between Marlowe and the door.
The girl can go. But I'd like to talk to you a little. Marlowe stares at him, then makes a slight motion toward the gun inside his coat.
Don't try it. I've got two boys outside in the car. He turns, opens the door, Carmen scuttles through it. Mar shuts the door behind her, looks about the room.  54.
(puts hat back on) There's something wrong around here. I intend to find out what it is. If you want to pick lead out of yourself, go ahead.
A tough guy. Mars makes no answer. He walks on into the room, looking around. Marlowe watches him.

I suppose it's all right if I smoke. Mars does not answer. He looks about, sees the totem pole is astonished, approaches it, stops suddenly as he moves the small rug over the bloodstain with his foot, then kneels swiftly out of sight for an instant beyond the des When he rises, he is facing Marlowe and his hand is just emerging from inside his coat, holding a Luger pistol.
Blood. On the floor there, under the rug. Quite a lot of blood.

(in interested tone) Is that so? Mars slides into the chair behind the desk, still watchin Marlowe, hooks the telephone toward him with the pistol- barrel, then shifts the pistol to his left hand and puts his right hand on the phone but without raising it.
I think we'll have some law. Marlowe approaches while Mars watches him, and looks down at the stain, pretends to have seen it for the first time
That's old blood. Dried.
Just the same, we'll have some law.
Why not?
Just who are you anyway?  55.
Marlowe's the name. I'ma private detective.
Who's the girl?
A client. Geiger was trying to throw a loop on her. We came to talk it over. He wasn't here.
Convenient -- the door being open, when you didn't have a key.
Wasn't it? By the way, how'd you happen to have one?
Is that any of your business?
I could make it my business.
(smiles tightly) And I could make your business mine.
You wouldn't like it. The pay's too small.
I own this house. Geiger is my tenant. Now what do you think of it?
You know some nice people.
I take them as they come. (he glances down at the pistol, shrugs, puts it back inside coat) Got any ideas, detective?  56.

One or two. Somebody gunned Geiger. Somebody got gunned by Geiger, who ran away. Or Geiger was running a cult and made blood sacrifices in front of that barber pole there. Or he had meat for dinner and does his butchering in the front parlor. (Mars scowls at him) All right. I'll give up, then. Call your friends downtown.
I don't get it. I still don't get your game here.
Don't you, Mr. Mars? Mars stares et Marlowe, who meets his stare steadily. Mars' face is now hard.
You seem to be telling me Geiger was in a racket of some sort. What racket?

I don't know. I'm not his landlord. And I'll tell you something else you missed. Somebody cleaned out whatever was in that back room in his bookshop today. Mars stares at Marlowe a long moment. Marlowe takes out a cigarette deliberately, is starting to light it.

You talk too much. While Marlowe stands, the cigarette in his mouth, the matchbox resting in his hands, Mars suddenly whips out th pistol again, holds it on Marlowe, and whistles shrilly. SOUND of car door SLAMMING OFF, then RUNNING FEET.
Open the door.

Open it yourself. I've already got a client.  57. Mars rises, still holding the pistol on Marlowe, crosses toward the door as the SOUND OF FEET reaches the door and the knob is rattled from outside. Mars reaches the door opens it. Two men plunge into the room, already reaching inside their coats. One is a young hoodlum, good-looking, pale-faced boy, the other is older, slim, deadpan.

(jerks his head at Marlowe) Look him over... The slim man flicks out a short pistol, covers Marlowe. The boy approaches, searches Marlowe, who turns, helping the boy search him with the burlesqued air of a bored beauty modeling a gown in a shop.
Okay. No iron.
Find who he is. The boy draws Marlowe's wallet from his breast pocket, flips it open, studies the contents.

A shamus. He strikes. Marlowe, moving faster, catches his wrist, wrenches it suddenly and sharply, so that in the next instant the wallet is in Marlowe's hand. The boy reacts angrily, but Mars stops it.
(sharply) That'll do. Beat it. The boy stops sullenly, glaring at Marlowe.
(coldly vicious) I said, outside. The two guards withdraw, exit.
All right. Talk. Marlowe deliberately finishes lighting the cigarette, inhales.  58.
Not to you. I told you I've already got a client.
Who was it cleaned out the back of Geiger's store?
Quite a shower yesterday. Did it rain up there at Las Olindas?
(slaps the pistol angrily down on the desk) I might even make it worth your while to talk to me.
That's the spirit. Leave the gun out of it. I can always hear money. How much of it are you clinking at me?
(slams the desk again with the flat pistol) I ask you a question, and you ask me another. My guess is, you need some help yourself. So cough up.

Not me. It's Geiger's kinfolk that need help -- provided a man like Geiger had anybody who loved him and will care who bumped him off. So I'd better give what I know to the Law. Which puts it in the public domain and don't leave me anything to sell. So I guess I'll drift. Marlowe makes a move to lift the gun, but does not.
(easily) By the way, how's Mrs. Mars these days? Mars' hand jerks at the gun, almost lifts it, pauses. He glares at Marlowe.  71. 72. 73. 59.
(almost whispers: raging inside) Beat it. Get out of here. Marlowe moves easily and unhurriedly toward the door.

as Marlowe gets into his car. A short distance behind it Mars' car is parked, the two guards in it. Marlowe drives away. He expects a shot perhaps. As he drives away he burlesques it: holds his hand out the window as if he wer testing the air for rain. He drives on.
sitting at his desk, the phone pulled up in front of him. He smokes nervously -- he seems to have been waiting some time -- and glances at his wristwatch. The PHONE RINGS. He grabs it.

Yeah... What's the news?... Nothing -- you mean they haven't called you? (smiling sardonically) Mrs. Rutledge... You are not a very good liar. I thought you were going to trust me... (jerking the phone away from his ear with exaggerated haste) Why, Mrs. Rutledge! The PHONE CLICKS LOUDLY as the other end is slammed down the hook. Marlowe replaces his instrument slowly. He is not clowning now. He speaks softly to the telephone as though to Vivian herself, half in admiration, half in anger.
You crazy darn fool... He picks up his hat and goes out.
on Marlowe, parked a few doors from the Randall Arms, obviously waiting for something.  74. 75. 76. 60.
as Vivian drives up, parks, and enters the apartment.

as Marlowe climbs the last steps. He walks down the hall to 405 and presses the bell. In one of the other apartments a radio plays softly.
