Geiger?
(after a pause, deadpan) You said what?
Geiger. Arthur Gwynne Geiger. The guy with the blackmail racket. Brody's right hand drops slowly out of sight -- we get th impression he's reaching for a gun.
Don't know anybody by that name. Marlowe gives him a hard smile. Brody doesn't like the smile.
You're Joe Brody?
So what?
So you're Joe Brody -- and you don't know anybody named Geiger. That's very funny.  77. 61.
Yeah? You got a funny sense of humor, maybe. Take it away and play it somewhere else. Marlowe leans against the door and gives him a dreamy smile.
You got Geiger's stuff, Joe. I got his sucker list. We ought to talk things over.

(glancing sideways into the room, then back to Marlowe) There's plenty of time to talk. Make it tomorrow, bud. He starts to close the door. Marlowe bares his teeth and shoves the door in against Brody, viciously.
(pleasantly) We'll make it now.

A pleasant room, nicely furnished. French windows open onto a balcony; near the windows a closed door, and near the entrance another door with a heavy curtain drawn acro it. Marlowe closes the entrance door behind him, not taking his eyes from Brody. Brody stands still, his hand frozen underneath his coat, his eyes wolfish. Presently h breaks, letting his hand drop.
(shrugging -- turning away) Why not, if you think you got something. Marlowe smiles, glancing at the curtained doorway. A woman's shoes show below the edge.
You alone, Joe?
(meaningfully) Yeah. Marlowe lifts the curtain, high enough to show a very spiffy leg -- Vivian's, in fact. He admires it.  62.

I could be alone with that almost any time. He drops the curtain again, goes to the davenport, and si down, tossing his hat beside him. Brody picks up a box of cigars from a nearby table, walks to an easy chair opposi Marlowe, and sits.
Well, I'm listening. He drops his cigarette stub into a tray and puts a cigar between his lips.
Cigar? He tosses one to Marlowe through the air. As Marlowe reaches out to catch it Brody takes a Police Special out the cigar box and covers Marlowe, who relaxes slowly, lik a steel spring.
Okay, stand up. Slow.

(not moving, smiling sardonically) My, my -- such a lot of guns around town, and so few brains. You're the second guy I've met today who seems to think a gat in the hand means the world by the tail. (derisively) Put it down, Joe. (as Joe doesn't move, only looks nastier) The other guy's name is Eddie Mars. Ever hear of him?
No.
If he ever gets wise to where you were last night in the rain -- you'll hear of him.
(deadpan, but lowering the gun) What would I be to Eddie Mars?  63.
Not even a memory.
Don't get me wrong. I'm not a tough guy -- just careful.
You're not careful enough. That play with Geiger's stuff was terrible. I saw it, you know. I don't think Geiger's boy friend liked it.
Carol Lundgren? That punk.

Yeah. Punk burns, sometimes. (raises his voice to the curtain door) You might as well come out, Vivian. Brody decided not to shoot me just yet. (as the curtain parts slightly to show Vivian, undecided) Oh, yeah, and bring the blonde with you. Vivian comes out, followed by Agnes. Vivian looks strained, angry, indomitable. Agnes looks merely vicious.
(to Agnes) Hello, sugar.

(sourly) Hello -- trouble! Agnes flounces down on the arm of an overstuffed chair. Brody watches, his eyes hard and narrow, expressionless. Vivian stands looking down at Marlowe. She is definitely not glad to see him.
So you don't really believe in miracles -- or me.
I've learned not to believe in anything. I don't need you, Marlowe. I don't know how you got here, but I don't want you. Will you get out?  64.
But darling, the man with the gun won't let me. Look -- he's all bothered and curious, wondering about stuff.

(menacingly) Yeah -- you bet I'm wondering. (looking sharply from Vivian to Marlowe, then to Agnes) Agnes -- put some more light on so I can see to shoot if I have to. (to Vivian, as Agnes switches on a floor lamp) You -- sit down, and keep quiet.
Joe, I swear I didn't have anything to do...

(attempting to draw her down beside him) Don't argue with the man. Here... (taking Vivian's handbag, hefting it to assure himself the wad of bills is still inside, and grinning with satisfaction, placing bag on couch) Sit on this, baby... Go ahead. You won't need it.
Marlowe, you're ruining everything.

(finally losing patience, yanking her down bodily) Sit down! Vivian struggles with him angrily. Marlowe puts his arm around her and smiles mockingly at Brody, who raises his gun slightly, with unpleasant significance.
Okay, fella. Give out.  He rises, his sheer 65.
(shaking his head) Uh-uh, Joe -- you're doing the giving.
(leaning forward, menacingly) Listen...
Sure, sure -- You're the hard boy with the gun. Okay -- go ahead, blow holes in me. That won't take the cops off your neck.
What cops?
The cops that are going to find out where all that lead in Geiger came from. pacing with nervous catlike energy as he talks, ease and conviction holding Brody motionless.

You shot Geiger, last night in the rain. The trouble is he wasn't alone when you whiffed him. Either you didn't notice that -- and I think you did -- or you got scared and ran. But you had nerve enough to take the plate out of his camera, and you had nerve enough to come back later and hide his corpse, so you could clean out his store before the law knew it had a murder to investigate.
(dangerously quiet) It's kind of lucky for you I didn't kill Geiger.
You can hold your breath for it, just the same.
You think you got me framed.  66.
Don't go simple on me, Joe. I told you there was a witness.
(suddenly seeing the light) Carmen! That little... She would -- just that! Vivian reacts to this -- Marlowe puts his hand strongly o her shoulder, holding her quiet!

(laughing) I thought you had that picture of her. For a moment nobody moves. There is a feeling of predator animals; caged and waiting. Vivian looks slowly up into Marlowe's face. Then Brody puts his gun down on an end table by his chair.
Let's all calm down here. Let's all just sit quiet a minute and think. (to Marlowe) Who are you? And what do you get out of this?
I'm just a guy paid to do other people's laundry. And all I get out of it is those pictures of Carmen.
What pictures?
(as to a child) Oh, Joe! He sits down beside Vivian again, talks to her as though Brody were not present.

How do you like that? He drops the whole thing in my lap, and then he says "What pictures"? (to Agnes) Poor Aggie. I hate to think of you standing outside the gas chamber watching him while he chokes.  67.
(to Brody) Joe...
Shut up. (to Marlowe) How did you get to me?
I never saw so many streets leading to one place in my life. Everywhere I turn I fall over Joe Brody -- and I been doing a lot of turning.
So Carmen says I gunned him.
With the photos in hand, I might be able to convince her she was wrong.

(after a pause, scowling) I'm not saying I have or haven't got the photos. I'm only saying I'm broke. Agnes and I are down to nickels, and we got to move on for a while till this Geiger thing cools off.
No dough from my client.

(to Vivian -- with cold fury) So you did go to somebody after all. (rising) All right! I don't need your five grand. I can take you off my back Marlowe, and I can get the cops taken off. I got a connection, see? I got a handle on something big enough to turn this town upside down --
Why haven't you pulled it?
I'm going to. And what I get out of it will make your five grand look like a roll of nickels.  68.
Joe -- you're not gonna do it. You can't go up against Eddie Mars, he'll --

(furiously) Shut up! You have to let that big mouth run off in front of -- He is interrupted by the sudden RINGING of the DOORBELL. They hold it, all of them apprehensive of who may be on t other side of the door, while the RINGING STOPS and becom an insistent rapping. Brody jerks open a desk drawer and draws out a bone-handled automatic, which he hands out to Agnes. She takes it, shaking nervously. Brody indicates Marlowe.

(to Agnes) If he gets funny, use your own judgment -- and the dame, too. Agnes sits on the arm of the davenport beside Marlowe, th gun out of sight against him. Marlowe, observing her shaking hand, is not happy. Brody puts his own gun in his pocket, leaving his hand on it, and opens the door. Carme Sternwood pushes him back in the room, using a tiny revolver which she pushes against his hips. Carmen kicks the door shut behind her; Agnes leaps up, standing out of Marlowe's reach, her gun wavering between him and Carmen. She remains oblivious of the other people in the room. Vivian reacts to her entrance, but says nothing. Marlowe sits still, automatically stroking the sleepy cat.
(to Brody, with quiet viciousness) I want my pictures, Joe. Brody is scared, playing it very easy, backing up as she follows him.
Take it easy, Carmen.
(sharply, eyeing Agnes) Carmen...
(to Carmen) Get away from him, you.  69. Vivian rises sharply, also getting out of Marlowe's reach she whips a small automatic out of her coat pocket.
(to Agnes, trying to watch her and Brody at the same time) Let her alone. (to Brody, moving toward him) Joe, if you dare to hurt her...
This is cute. Hasn't anybody else got a gun? -- We can play ring around the roses.
(ignoring them all -- to Brody) You shot Arthur Geiger. I saw you. I want my pictures.

For Pete's sake, all of you -- relax! No one hears him. The three women continue to behave like nervous cats -- the lead may start flying at anybody, any minute. Brody still has his hand in his pocket; he may blast Carmen -- and Marlowe, gunless, sits in the middle the possible crossfire. Vivian is closer to him than Agnes, having moved beyond the hampering arm of the couch Marlowe moves abruptly. Grabbing the couch cushion which Vivian has just vacated, he slings it at Agnes, knocking her off balance and down. Almost as a continuation of the same movement Marlowe mak a dive for Vivian's legs. She falls on top of him, they struggle for the gun, and Vivian bites Marlowe's wrist. H whacks her across the side of the head with his free hand wrenches the gun free and stands up. Carmen's attention has been distracted slightly by this dust-up, and Brody strikes at her gun hand. The gun goes off, making a small sharp crack, shattering a pane of glass in the French windows, then skitters out of Carmen's hand and across th floor. Agnes lets go a frightened bleat and collects herself, about to fire at Carmen. Marlowe makes a quick rush, kicks the gun out of her hand, and puts his foot on Carmen's gun just as Carmen gets there, her hands and knees, reaching. She puts her hand on Marlowe's foot, and then looks up at him, sidewise, and giggles. He bends ove and pats her on the back.  70.
Get up, angel. You look like a Pekinese. She draws back and rises as Marlowe scoops up her gun wit his left hand and drops it in his pocket. The gun he has taken from Vivian still dominates the room.

Everybody -- stand still. They do, and he walks over and picks up Agnes' gun, sticking that on in his hip pocket. Brody is wiping the nervous sweat off his face -- Agnes and Vivian still crou half stunned on the floor. Marlowe laughs.

My, don't we have fun! You can get up now, kiddies. (walking over to Brody) All right, Joe. Give. Brody goes sullenly to the desk, opens a secret compartme and pulls out a fat envelope, hands it to Marlowe. Marlow glances at the contents.
Sure this is all of it?
Yeah. Now will you dust, so I can air out the room? Marlowe turns as the Sternwood girls approach him. Carmen gives him a languishing smile and holds out her hand for the envelope.
Can I have them now?
I'll take care of them for you. He hands the envelope to Vivian, who thanks him with her eyes.
(to Carmen and Vivian) You'd better go on home now. Carmen continues to look at him, sidelong, biting her thu
You'll take care of Carmen, won't you?  71.
Check.
Could I have my gun back?
Later.
You're awfully cute.

Yeah. (stopping Vivian as she passes him, heading toward the door) Countess -- you forgot something. He picks up her bag off the davenport and hands it to her -- the scene's almost a repetition of the one in Marlowe' office, with Marlowe still holding the handbag.
Did I hurt your head much?
(softly) You -- and every other man I ever met. She goes out. Carmen follows her, but at the door she turns impulsively, flings her arms around Marlowe's neck and kisses him.

I like you. She runs off down the hall. Marlowe looks at her, puzzled by her unusual attitude. He closes the door and turns again to Brody and Agnes. Agnes, considerably scratched up, gives him a snakely glare as she pats her wounds with handkerchief.
I got enough of you, chum.
Yeah, but there's still some unfinished business. What's this handle you got on Eddie Mars that's big enough to turn the town upside down?  72.
Listen -- you got your pictures -- you got nothing more on me. Get outta here.

Sure, I can go. You can go, too. Up to Quentin, to the big chair in the little room with the window. They stand outside, Joe, with stopwatches. They clock you in seconds, but from where you sit the centuries stink of cyanide, and they wrap around your throat, and a lot of people say it's easier than hanging -- I don't know.
What are you trying to do?
Keep your neck out of a noose -- in return for some information. Got an alibi for last night?
I was right here with Agnes.
(picking up his hat) Okay, Joe. You can only die once, even for a couple of murders. Brody stares at him as he turns to leave. Agnes is scared -- she puts her hand on Brody's shoulder.
Wait a minute. What do you mean -- a couple of murders?
But then, you don't have to worry, do you? You got a connection.
Sit down.
(laughs, sits down on table edge) Where were you about seven-thirty last night?  73.

(sullenly) Watching Geiger's place, to see if he has any friends too big for me to kick out of the way when I take over his business. It's raining hard, I'm shut up in my car, and I don't see anything except another car parked in the alley below Geiger's. I look at it -- it's a Buick registered to Mrs. Rutledge. That's all. Nothing happened, and I got tired waiting and went home.
Know where that Buick is now?
How would I?

In the Sheriff's garage. It was fished out of twelve feet of water off Lido pier this morning. There was a dead man in it, Owen Taylor, the Sternwood's chauffeur -- the guy you got the pictures from. He'd been sapped and the car pointed out the pier and the hand throttle pulled down. Brody gives Marlowe a stricken look. Agnes tightens her grip on him.
Joe, you didn't...
Shut up. (to Marlowe) You can't hang that one on me.
I can make a good try -- unless you talk and talk straight.
All right, all right! Yeah, I heard the shots. I see this guy come slamming down the back steps with something in his hand. (MORE )

He shoots off in the Buick, and I follow him, and out of the highway he skids off the road and has to stop, so I stop too, and play cop. His nerve is bad, and I sap him down -- and I figure the film might be worth something, so I take it. That's the last I see of him.
Uh-huh -- so Taylor gave Geiger the works, and ail for the love of little Carmen. Agh! The sap!... How'd you know it was Geiger he shot?
Seemed like a good guess. When I saw what was on the film I was sure, and when Geiger didn't show at the store this morning, Agnes and I figured it was a good time to do ourselves some business.
Yeah, you figured, all right. You businessed yourself right into a hot box.
Yeah -- yeah, I guess I did.
I got connections too, you know, with the D.A.'s office. If I know about Eddie Mars I might be able to cool you down some.
(as Brody hesitates) Go on, Joe -- tell him!
Okay. It's kind of a funny story. It ain't about Eddie Mars, really -- it's about his wife. I... The DOORBELL starts to RING. Brody stands up, with Agnes beside him. Marlowe stays put.
If she is, she doesn't have her gun. Don't you have any other friends?

(crossing to the table, picking up the Colt) Just about one. (going angrily to the door) I got enough of this. He opens the door about a foot, with his left hand, holdi the Colt ready by his thigh. It is impossible to see who stands in the hall. Almost instantly two shots sound, close together. Brody doubles up, falls forward against the door, slamming it shut. Agnes reacts, but does not scream. Marlowe leaps up, hauls Brody away from the door -- Brody is quite dead. Marlowe runs out.
as Marlowe runs toward the stairs. A frightened woman peers out of a doorway, pointing to the stairs. The SOUND of RUNNING FEET comes from the treads below. Marlowe race to the stairway and down.
The front door is closing itself quietly as Marlowe races down the last flight of steps. He goes through the door catching it before it closes.
as Marlowe comes out, pauses to get his bearings.
He runs between two parked cars diagonally across the street, whirls to fire.
as two shots sound -- we see the impact of the bullets on the wall beside Marlowe, too close for comfort.
(MARLOWE'S ANGLE)
as Lundgren vanishes behind parked cars, in the dense tre shadows, running hard.  84. 85. 86. 87. 76.
as Marlowe gets in his car and heads down the street, following Lundgren.

a quiet residential street, with trees growing heavy alon the parkway. Marlowe's car pulls in to park. Marlowe gets out into the street, crouching low, and pulls Carmen's little gun from his pocket. He walks back the way he has come, crouching for shelter behind the line of parked car Aside from him the street is deserted.
as Carol Lundgren walks unconcernedly along, approaching Marlowe. He seems to feel that he's in the clear, even whistles softly as he walks.
As Lundgren draws abreast of him, Marlowe steps from between the parked cars, holding the gun at his side. An unlighted cigarette droops from his lips.

Got a match, bud? Lundgren stands still, taken by surprise, not sure what t do. His hand rises instinctively to his leather jacket, but not inside. A siren wails off, going toward the Randall Arms -- Lundgren turns his head instinctively toward the sound, and Marlowe steps in against him, the little gun jammed into Lundgren's midriff.
Me, or the cops?
Get away from me.

This is a small gun, kid. I can give it to you through the belly and in three months you'll be well enough to walk the last mile up at Quentin.  88. 89. 77. Lundgren holds it, glaring at Marlowe, then relaxes.
What do you want?
(turning -- indicating car) Get into my car, kid. (as Lundgren obeys -- slowly) Under the wheel. You drive.
As Lundgren slides under the wheel, from the curb side, and Marlowe gets in beside him, keeping him covered.

Let's go to Laverne Terrace -- Geiger's house. (pleasantly -- as Lundgren starts the car) And by the way, Carol -- if you shot Brody for friendship's sake, you shot the wrong guy. Lundgren gives him a hard, nasty look and laughs.
(softly) Not all friendship, was it? Yeah, money talks, all right. It talks, and it's breath smells of blood... (laughing to himself) I told Brody that sometimes punk burns...
Marlowe and Lundgren stand on the footbridge. Marlowe still carries the toy gun. He pulls the keys out of his pocket with his left hand and gives them to Lundgren.

You open it. Lundgren starts to take the keys, then slams Marlowe a quick, hard punch on the jaw. Marlowe rocks back, but doesn't fall -- he smiles and throws the gun down at Lundgren's feet.  90. 91. 78.

Maybe you need this. Lundgren goes for the gun. As he bends down Marlowe steps in fast, bringing his knee up into Lundgren's face. The force of the blow straightens Lundgren up, and Marlowe uncorks a terrific left. Lundgren falls heavily. Marlowe, unperturbed, unlocks the door, puts the gun back in his pocket, and starts to drag Lundgren inside.

Lundgren is stretched out on the couch, his hands bound behind him, under his back. A single lamp shines down int his face. He has bled somewhat from the nose. Marlowe sits on the couch, twisted sideways, so that Lundgren's head is strained back over his knee. Marlowe helps the straining by having his left hand wound in Lundgren's hai His manner is gentle, almost friendly.

(softly) You're going to cop a plea, brother -- don't ever think you're not. And when you talk, you're going to say just what I want you to say, and nothing else. You hear me, sweetheart? Lundgren makes no reply, staring stonily into the light.
(almost caressingly) It's your face, Carol. You can do what you want with it. He jerks Lundgren's head back harder and raises his free hand, bringing it down.

Marlowe stands at the telephone, speaking into the instrument. His face is beaded with sweat, his collar open. He smokes jerkily -- we get the impression he hasn' enjoyed slapping Lundgren around. In b.g. Lundgren lies on the couch, both hands over his face.  92. 93. 79.
(into phone) Hello, Bernie? -- Yeah, Marlowe. How you fixed for red points, Bernie...? Well, come on up to 7244 Laverne Terrace -- I got some cold meat set out... might interest you.

They stand by the bed, looking down. Geiger is laid out on the bed. Two strips of Chinese embroidery cover the wounds on his breast, in the shape of a cross, his hands folded over them. The only light in the room comes from two black candles burning on either side of the bed.
Nice gesture of friendship. Lundgren?
Yeah. Ohls bends over, lifts up the Chinese embroidery, studies Geiger's chest, then straightens up.
So that's where the three slugs went out of Owen Taylor's gun. Well, I can understand that. (making a gesture of distaste) Let's get out of here.

sprawled sideways on the couch, leaning his head against the wall, showing signs of his recent battle with Marlowe Marlowe sits in b.g., easily, smoking. Ohls stands over Carol. Ohls is annoyed with Marlowe, shows it in succeeding scenes.
(to Carol) Do you admit shooting Brody?
(not moving -- not opening his eyes) Take a jump, Jack.  94. 95. 80.
(through smoke) He doesn't have to admit it. I've got the gun.
(he rouses himself) I've called Wilde. Come on. We'll deliver this punk to him. He leans down, grasps Carol's arm.

Get up. (Carol flings his hand off -- rises sullenly -- Ohls moves in beside him) Come on, Marlowe. The D.A. will want to see the man that solves single-handed what we make busts on. And on the way to him, you and I will talk a little too. Marlowe rises, follows as Ohls takes Carol out, snapping off the lights as he passes them and all exit.

indicating a city of some size, wealth, etc. The D.A. sit behind his desk. He wears a dinner jacket, has been calle hastily from a party obviously. At corner of the desk sit Captain Cronjager of the city police homicide detail, in plain clothes. He is a cold, hatchet-faced man obviously displeased with the way things have happened. Ohls enters followed by Marlowe.

(to Wilde) Evening, Chief. Evening, Cronjager. (he pulls up a chair to sit down) Meet Sherlock Holmes, gentlemen. (to Marlowe) Grab yourself a chair -- unless you'd rather be on your feet while Cronjager gives you a going-over.  81.
Sit down, Marlowe. We'll try to handle Captain Cronjager. But I think you'll admit you were going a little fast, won't you?
Thanks. He sits down, takes out a cigarette, holds it unlighted i his hand. Ohls and Cronjager stare at him.
Fast is right. But just wait and watch him go when his foot finally does slip. (to Cronjager) Maybe you'd better tell Sherlock Holmes here what else you got on the Randall Place killing.

A blonde. Down on the street, trying to start a car that didn't belong to her. Hers was right next to it, the same model. She acted rattled, so the boys brought her in and she spilled. Claims she didn't see the killer.

(still riding Marlowe) He's in the back office now -- handcuffed. Here's the gun. He takes Carol's gun from his pocket, drops it on the des Cronjager looks at the gun, but without touching it. Afte a moment Wilde chuckles, enjoying Cronjager's discomfitur and Ohls' annoyance.
But that's just one of them. (he stares at Marlowe while he addresses Cronjager ) You heard about a car being lifted out of the surf at Lido pier this morning with a dead guy in it?
(mildly) Do you have to be coy about it?

(staring at Marlowe -- addressing Cronjager with malicious sarcasm) Sure. The guy they found drowned in the car shot another guy last night in your territory; a guy named Geiger who ran a racket in the back room of a bookstore on the boulevard. The punk I got in the back office worked for Geiger. (to Marlowe) You're on the air. Let's have it.

That's all. When I finally located the lad that moved the packing case out of Geiger's back room, Geiger's blonde secretary was with him. It was Brody. While I was trying to persuade Brody to tell what became of the packing case, the doorbell rang again and Brody opened the door and somebody shot him twice. You know the rest of it. (he lights his cigarette)
Except what was in the packing case -- yes.
(smoking) Brody didn't tell me.
(staring at Marlowe) You see, Cronjager? Even as smart as he is, he's got to guess sometimes, too.
My guess is the same as yours. Black mailing stuff. Geiger's customers must have been wearing a path across that rug, coming in to knock on that locked door and pay their monthly installments.  83.
(staring at Marlowe) That's right, Cronjager. Maybe Sherlock's even going to show us his evidence for guessing that.
Do you folks still guess when you have evidence?

(sharply) That's enough of this. (to Marlowe) So Taylor killed Geiger because he was in love with the Sternwood girl. And Brody followed Taylor, sapped him and took the photograph and pushed Taylor into the ocean. And the punk killed Brody because the punk thought he should have inherited Geiger's business and Brody was throwing him out.
That's how I figure it.
(extends his hand) Let's see your evidence.

Give, pal. Hiding murders. Spending a whole day foxing around so that this punk of Geiger's can have plenty of time to commit another one. Marlowe takes from his coat and puts on the desk before Wilde the three notes and Geiger's card to General Stern wood, and the notebook with its code list of names. Wilde looks at them, lights a cigar. Ohls and Cronjager rise an look at the articles over Wilde's shoulders. Marlowe smokes quietly.
(after a time) These notes. If General Sternwood paid them, it would be because he was afraid of something else. Do you know what he was afraid of?
No.  84. Wilde stares at Marlowe.
(after a moment) Have you told your story complete?

But don't you want me to try?
(trying to free his hand now) I just want you to get out of here.
(clinging to his hand) You've got funny thumbs. Can I bite it? Before he can answer, she raises his hand, starts to put his thumb into her mouth. With a sharp violent motion he flings her hand away.
Stick to your own thumb. Hasn't it carried you all right all your life?

Okay. Take your thumb now and get out of here.

(seething with repressed rage; almost whispering) Get out.

And beyond him?
So you want to know. Okay it came from your client. That satisfy you?
I haven't got a client. General Sternwood paid me off yesterday. I'm through.

Well, apparently he don't think so. And he's a friend of the D.A. and the D.A. is the chief crime prosecutor of this county, and I'm the D.A.'s head man Friday, and all three of us tell you to lay off.
Will you tell me one more thing: Why General Sternwood thinks I haven't laid off?
No. But I'll tell you what he might be thinking. That you are trying to uncover enough stuff about his family affairs to put the squeeze on him yourself.
That's a lie. General Sternwood never told the D.A. nor you nor anybody else that. I don't think the message even came from General Sternwood. It was -- (he stops, but Ohls has already broken in)
Never you mind what you think. You just lay off. You get it?
(quietly) I get it. Or else I lose my license and take my pick and shovel out of the mothballs.  118. Thoughtful, he reaches out and takes a cigarette from the box.
(watching him) Changed your mind, huh?
(recovers, sees the cigarette in his hand, drops it back into the box) No. I haven't changed it.
The TELEPHONE IS RINGING. Marlowe takes it up.
Yes, speaking --
She wears hat and coat as if about to depart.
(rapidly) I've found Shawn. I'm leaving at once to meet him. We'll send you a picture postal from Mexico perhaps. So you can call off the bloodhounds, and many thanks. (she hangs up)
as the click of Vivian's phone comes through it.
facing Norris, who has answered the bell. Norris stands holding the door half open, as if barring Marlowe from entering.

So she found him.
(inscrutable) Yes, Sir. We are all most happy. -- Was there anything else?
The General...
Is resting. I won't disturb him now.
Thanks. Norris watches him, still barring him from entering. He turns. Norris closes the door. Marlowe walks on.
the same car which was following Marlowe yesterday. Marlo passing, recognizes it, pauses, thoughtful, walks on.
as he passes the mouth of a narrow alley two men step out quickly. One of them saps Marlowe expertly -- they drag him out of sight.

(gently) This is just our way of saying -- lay off. Get it, Marlowe? Lay off. He boots Marlowe in the stomach -- the pair of them depar while Marlowe is getting rid of his breakfast. Yet in his wizened ugly face there is independence, honesty, reliability, courage. He helps Marlowe to his feet, steadies him, hand him a handkerchief.  133. 120.
(still groggy -- wiping his face) You're the guy that's been tailing me.
Yeah. The name's Jones. Harry Jones. I want to see you.
That's swell. Did you want to see those two guys jump me?
I didn't care one way or the other.
You could have yelled for help.
A guy's playing a hand, I let him play it. I'm no kibitzer.
(grinning) You got brains. Come on up to the office.
Marlowe removes his coat and hat, hangs them up. Jones watches him. Marlowe is reasonably steady now, gradually getting his wind back.

Might as wall take yours off too. We may be here a good while, unless I get another case. He goes to the desk, sits down, lights a cigarette, pours stiff shot from the office bottle, then starts to riffle through a small stack of mail on his desk. Jones watches him. He opens top letter, reads it.
I been around too. Used to runa little liquor. Rode the scout car with a Tommy gun in my lap. A tough racket.  121.
(reading, squinting through smoke) Terrible. He tosses the letter into wastebasket, takes up the next, opens it, sees Jones still standing.
Sit down. You make me nervous standing there. Jones sits on edge of a chair; Marlowe opens and rapidly reads the next letter, tosses it in wastebasket, opens the next one. Jones watches him.
Maybe you don't believe me.
(throws letter into wastebasket) What do you want?
(approvingly, man to man fashion) That's better. I got something to sell -- cheap, for a couple of C's.
(opens next letter) Then don't let me stop you.
(baffled) Don't you even want to know who I am?

(rapidly reading letter) I already know. You're not a cop. You don't belong to Eddie Mars, because I asked him. (throws last letter into wastebasket, sits back and looks at Jones) So Agnes is loose again, huh?
(taken aback) How'd you know?  122.
Well -- she's a blonde.
She's a nice girl. We're talking of getting married.
She's too big for you. She'll roll on you and smother you.
(injured) That's a dirty crack, brother.
You're right. I've been running around with the wrong people lately. Let's cut out the babble. What do you want?
You're looking for something. Will you pay for it?
If it does what?
Helps you find Regan.
Is that what you want the two C's for -- for telling me I'm looking for Regan? People have been telling me that for two days now. I don't even give cigars for it anymore.
(patiently) Do you want to know what I got, or don't you?
I don't know. Two C's buys a lot of information in my circle.
Would you pay two hundred dollars to know where Eddie Mars' wife is? Would you pay two hundred bucks for that, shamus?  123.
(leans forward and rubs out cigarette) I think I would. Where?
Agnes found her. She'll tell you -- when she has the money in her hand.
You might tell the coppers for nothing.
(quietly) I ain't so brittle.
(speculatively) Agnes must have something I didn't notice.

(quietly, with dignity even) I ain't tried to pull anything. I come here with a straight proposition -- take it or leave it; one right guy to another. Then you start waving cops at me. You ought to be ashamed of yourself.
(quietly too) I am -- Okay. Two hundred it is. I'll have to go to the bank
(rises) Okay. After dark'll be better anyway. You know Puss Walgreen's office -- Fulwider building -- four-twenty-eight at the back?
I can find it.
I'll meet you there at seven o'clock tonight. You bring the money, and I'll take you to Agnes. Okay?  134. 135. 136. 137. 138. 124.
Okay.
(going out) So long then. He exits.
Marlowe enters.
It is deserted. Marlowe pauses at elevator, the door is open, a shabby old man is asleep on the stool. Marlowe goes on.
pushes the door open, enters stairs, door closes behind h

(purring) I thought you'd remember. Marlowe steals quietly back along the wall, reaches anoth door, pushes it quietly. It is locked. He takes out his wallet, removes his driver's license from its celluloid, takes the envelope and slips back the door-lock, opens th door carefully and quietly, enters, shuts the door.

as he stands beside an inner door which is slightly open, light burning beyond it. Through the crack in the door Harry Jones can be seen, sitting behind a shabby desk. Th other man, CANINO, is not in sight at this angle.  125. Jones is sweating; he cannot help that. But there is no fear in his voice and he is not trembling either.
So you go to see this peeper, this Marlowe. That was your mistake. Eddie don't like it. And what Eddie don't like ain't healthy.
You know why I went to the peeper. Account of Joe Brody's girl. She's got to blow. That takes dough. She figured the peeper could get it for her.
Dough for what?

You know about the night the kid bumped Brody? Well, the young Sternwood girl was there. She not only dropped in, she took a shot at Brody. Only the peeper didn't tell the cops that. So Agnes figures it's railroad fare for her as soon as she can get hold of the peeper. You get it?
Sure thing. Where's this Agnes?
What do you care? All she wants is to touch the peeper and blow -- His voice stops. He sits back, staring Canino off, shows terror now despite himself, but still no fear.
(purring) That's right. Look at it. You'll tell me, little man. Where's Agnes?
Listen --
You want me to count three or something, like a movie? Where's Agnes?  139. 126.
(gives in, collapses) You win. She's in an apartment at 28 Court. Apartment 501. I guess I'm yellow, all right.

You just got good sense. I ain't going to hurt her. If everything's like you say, I'll tell Eddie it's all jakeloo. We'll even dip the bill on it. As Canino's hand comes into sight setting a whiskey bottle on the desk, Marlowe steps quickly back.
Got a glass?

(stares at the bottle, hopeless now, sweating but still bravely) There at the cooler. As Canino enters, Marlowe steps quickly out. Canino crosses the open door. We now SEE HIM; a stocky, vicious man in brown: a killer.

beside the door. Jones cannot be seen now, only Canino as he takes the glass from water cooler and crosses the door again. Now he too is not visible. Marlowe follows him by SOUND ALONE as he returns to the table, clinks the bottle against the glass as he pours the drink.
(purring, falsely hearty) There you are. Drink her down. Mud in your eye. Jones' breathing can be heard as he pants. When Canino speaks next, his voice is a little sharper.
Drink it. What do you think it is -- poison? I bet that Agnes of yours wouldn't turn it down.  140. 141. 127.
No. (SOUND of his movement as he takes the glass) Success.

Lots of it. SOUND as Jones drinks, dies, the glass CLINKS as he drops it, his body thuds as he falls forward, gasps, chokes. Marlowe starts forward, catches himself. The other room goes dark. SOUND as Canino leaves it: his feet, the other door opens, closes again.

The door opens on the corridor. With the light gone, the glass in the door is faintly luminous, lettering in reverse, Canino's shadow across it. SOUND of his feet die away. Marlowe moves swiftly toward the inner door.

his hand on the switch as he turns on the light, looks fo an instant at Jones sprawled dead across the desk, the whiskey bottle and overturned glass beside him. Marlowe pauses only a second. He looks about, sees what he wants, crosses to telephone, takes it up, dials hurriedly.

(into phone) Information, can you give me the phone number of Apartment 301, 28 Court Street? (he lowers phone, waits, raises phone quickly again, listens attentively) Thanks. (puts phone down, takes it up again, dials) Is Agnes in? The VOICE that answers is a MAN'S VOICE, burly and loud, that it can be heard over the phone.
No Agnes here, buddy. what number you want?  128.
Wentworth two-five-two-eight.
Right number, wrong gal. Ain't it a shame!
Yeah. Can you put me back on to the switchboard?
Here you go. (phone clicks, whirrs)

Hello, Manager? This is Wallis, Police Identification Bureau, is there a girl named Agnes Lozelle registered at your place?... Well, have you got a tall blonde with green eyes, either alone, or witha little chap that weighs about a hundred pounds, green hat, gray overcoat... Yeah, must have been the wrong address. Thanks. He puts the phone down, turns, looks at Jones.

(musing aloud, with admiration) Well, you died like a poisoned rat. But you drank your poison like a man before you split on your girl, didn't you? He approaches, gingerly and carefully shifts Jones enough to reach inside his coat, is about to search Jones, the telephone rings. Marlowe pauses, thinks, makes decision, takes up phone.

(into phone) Yeah?... Hello, Agnes... Marlowe, the guy you want to see. No, he's not here. He's gone, beat it. But I've got the money. Where are you?... I don't know where he went. Do you want the two C's or don't you?... In half an hour. Right.  142. 143. 129. He puts the phone down, takes out his handkerchief and wipes his fingerprints off of it, crosses to the light switch, wipes it off too, turns it with the handkerchief, goes to the door, through which he came, exits.
as he wipes off the knob with his handkerchief.
as Marlowe gets into the car -- the gray Plymouth. Beyond the rain-streaked windows a Los Angeles street is visible lighted store windows, etc.
I thought you were never coming. Give me the money. Marlowe hands her folded bills. She counts them rapidly b the dash light, then puts them in her handbag.
This is a getaway stake, copper. I'm on my way. What happened to Harry?
I told you he ran away. Canino got wise to him somehow. Forget Harry. I've paid for information and I want it.

You'll get it. Joe and I were out riding Foothill Boulevard a couple weeks ago. We passed a brown coupe, and I saw the girl who was driving. She was Eddie Mars' wife. There was a guy with her -- the watchdog, Canino. They're people you don't forget, even if you only saw them once. So we got curious, and Joe tailed them. About a mile east of Realito there's a side road, and nothing around it but brush and hills. Just off the highway there's a two-bit garage and paintshop run by a guy named Art Huck -- hot car drop, likely -- and a frame house behind it. That's where Eddie Mars' wife is holed up.
(studying her coldly) You're sure of that?
Why should I lie?... Well, goodbye, copper -- wish me luck. I got a raw deal.
Yeah. Your kind always does. He turns and opens the door to get out.

Marlowe's car rushing along the wet highway, which now ru through barren country close to the foothills. The car takes an S curve, skidding dangerously.

At the door, as Marlowe goes up and hammers on it with th butt of his heavy flashlight. There is a moment of silence. Then the inside light goes off. Marlowe centers his flash in a white circle of light on the doors.
(speaking through the door) Whaddaya want?
Open up, I got two flats back on the highway and only one spare.

Sorry, mister. We're closed up. Better try Realito. Marlowe doesn't appreciate this. He kicks the door, hard, and keeps on kicking it, until a second voice -- Canino's voice -- speaks from close inside. Then he stops to listen.

Okay, Art -- open up for the wise guy. A BOLT SQUEALS, and half the door opens inward. Marlowe's flash outlines a gaunt hard face, Huck's face. Then Huck swings a gun down across the flash, knocking it out of Marlowe's hand, still burning.
Kill that spot, bud. Marlowe picks up the flash, turning it off. Light goes on inside the garage, revealing HUCK, a tall man in dirty coveralls. He backs away from the door, keeping Marlowe covered.
Come inside and shut the door.

as Marlowe closes the door behind him. There is the usual paraphernalia of a garage, and two cars. One is being painted, a spray-gun lying on the fender, the other is Carmen Sternwood's Packard convertible. Canino lounges easily in the shadows by the bench. The RAIN BEATS on the tin roof.  133.
(indicating Huck's gun) You could scare off a lot of trade that way.
I'm too far out of town to take chances. (pointedly) You can get yourself hurt, kicking on doors.
(softly) Cut it out, Art. You run a garage, don't you?
(not looking at Canino) Thanks. (to Huck) I suppose you can fix flats.
(putting the gun in his pocket) As good as you can make ‘em, bud. But right now I'm busy.
(pleasantly) Art -- you got time to fix his tires.
You can use my spare -- that'll help some.
Listen, I told you I'm busy with a spray job...
It's too damp for a good spray job, Art. Get moving -- and take two jacks.

Now wait a minute... Canino looks at Huck with a soft quiet-eyed stare, then away again, not saying anything. Huck wilts and moves pulling on a raincoat and banging out with a socket wrench, a hand jack, and wheeling a dolly.  160. 134. Canino closes the door behind him and returns to the workbench. Marlowe watches silently, lighting a cigarette
Bet you could use a drink. Wet the inside, and even up.

Thanks. Canino produces a bottle and two glasses from under the bench, pours two shots, and hands one to Marlowe. They salute -- Canino drinks, and Marlowe, remembering Harry Jones and the cyanide cocktail, hesitates, then drinks also.
(casually) Live around here?
No. Just got in from Reno and Carson City.
The long way round, huh? Business trip?
Partly. And in a hurry.
Too bad -- you may have a long wait. (reaching for Marlowe's empty glass) How about another, to pass the time.

-- the tire already on a spreader and loose from the rim. A man's hands and feet working at the job viciously. The CAMERA PULLS BACK to show Art Huck as he rips out the tub Marlowe and Canino stand almost as before, by the workbench.
(grumbling over above action) I don't have enough to do -- guys have to get flats in the middle of a cloudburst.  161. 135.

(laughing) Don't crab so much. You can use an extra bath. (taking a roll of coins out of his pocket, tossing them idly in the palm of his hand) Just get busy. Huck carries the tube to an airhose and starts to fill it

I am busy, brother. Plenty busy. He starts to place the tube in the galvanized tub under t hose, then turns swiftly, lifting the tube high, and brin it down over Marlowe's head and shoulders, a perfect ringer. Marlowe, unable to reach the gun in his pocket, bends forward, trying to throw Huck over his back. Canino steps in lightly, like a dancer, his hand closed hard ove the roll of coins, and hangs one with delicate precision Marlowe's jaw. Marlowe's tough -- he goes on fighting, although he's already out on his feet. Huck pulls his head back by the hair as Canino clips him again with the weighted fist. Marlowe tries, but it's no use. He goes down and stays that way.

A small room, in keeping with the exterior -- furnished comfortably but not luxuriously. The only light comes fro a floor lamp beside the davenport where Marlowe lies. His hands are cuffed behind him, his feet roped to the leg of the davenport. He is still out, his face considerably the worse for wear. Vivian sits beside him on a straight chair, holding a half empty glass in her hand. She seems to have forgotten about it. She seems to have forgotten everything but Marlowe -- who begins to come out of it. H opens his eyes presently and looks at Vivian -- he doesn' seem surprised. He winces and shuts his eyes again.
(thickly) Move the light, honey... Vivian rises and turns the light away from his face. He looks up at her again.  136.
(still groggy) That's better -- where are the boys -- out digging a grave?
(desperately) Phil, why did you have to go on with this?
Why did you? Vivian turns away from him -- she's obviously keyed up, scared, desperate.
I've only known one fool as big as you...
(after a pause) You might spare me a little of that drink you're not using. Vivian goes to him, sits down, and holds the glass to Marlowe's lips, then touches his battered face with her fingertips.
(shakily) Your face looks like a collision met...

It won't last long, even this good. (after a pause, looking up at Vivian softly) I'll give it back to you -- I've only known one fool as big as you. They hold it, a twisted uncomfortable moment, and then MO MARS enters. She is tall, blonde, strikingly beautiful -- a woman who knows her way around, yet having a certain dignity and fineness.
You would be Mrs. Eddie Mars... the blond that Shawn Regan didn't run away with.  137.

Why did you have to make trouble? Eddie wasn't doing you any harm. I was never in love with Shawn -- we were just good friends. But you know perfectly well that if I hadn't hid out here when Shawn disappeared, the police would have been certain Eddie killed him.
(quietly) But he did kill him.
(after a pause, with quiet dignity) Eddie's not that sort of man.
You mean Eddie never kills people.
No.
You really believe that, don't you? And in a way, I suppose you're right...
(sincerely) I'm married to Eddie Mars. I love him. I know what's inside of him.
Well, if Eddie's such a nice guy, I'd like to talk to him without Canino around. You know what Canino will do -- beat my teeth out and then kick me in the stomach for mumbling.
You'll get your talk, Phil. Canino's gone for Eddie.

Leaving Art Huck within call, I suppose. Well, I suppose nobody's luck holds forever. (to Vivian) You could really have gone to Mexico, you know. You'd have liked it better. Blood doesn't spatter that far.  138.
Oh, stop talking that way! Vivian and Marlowe are no longer conscious of her presenc having retired into a private world of their own.

But then you couldn't go, could you. The border police would have checked you through alone, and too many people might have seen you -- without Shawn Regan. Much safer to come down here with Mona. Much safer -- especially for Eddie Mars.
I did it as much for you... Why wouldn't you believe me? Why wouldn't you stop?
Too many people tried to make me. And besides I knew Shawn Regan -- and I know you. They look at each other -- and Mona Mars takes herself quietly out of the room.
Why did I have to meet you? Why out of all the men in the city, did my father have to call you in?

Things happen that way, sometimes... Light me a cigarette... She takes one from a table, lights it, and bends over to place it between Marlowe's lips. Marlowe's eyes hold her as though his hands were on her shoulders; she sits down.

(softly) You know what they're going to do, don't you? You know the only thing they can do. Vivian's hands grip the shoulders of his coat. She shuts her eyes and drops her head, holding herself rigid.  139.
(still softly) It's not pretty, is it -- even from a distance. And when you're right on top of it, it isn't pretty at all.
(rising abruptly) Oh, stop it, Phil. Stop it! Nothing's going to happen...

Mona's in love with Eddie Mars, but you're not. Are you going through with it? Vivian moves away, as far from him as she can get, and stands with her back to him, rigid, staring at the curtained window as though she could see through it. Marlowe studies her, then laughs, a quiet sardonic chuckl and relaxes, leaning back on the cushion.

Pride is a great thing, isn't it? And courage -- and honor -- and love. All the things you read about in the copybooks -- only in the copybooks nothing ever gets tangled. The road always lies so straight, and clear, and the signs say to love and honor and be brave... Take this thing out of my mouth, will you, honey? It's burning me. Vivian comes slowly to him and takes the cigarette stub from his lips. She hesitates, then goes down onto the couch, dropping the cigarette on the floor. Her arms go around Marlowe, her mouth crushed to his. When she breaks for air, putting her cheek against his, she is almost crying. Marlowe is far from unmoved himself, turning his head against hers, hard.

(after a pause, whispering) Get a knife, and cut this rope off me... Vivian rises, runs out of the room. The SOUND of a kitche drawer being opened comes OVER from o.s., then the RATTLE of CUTLERY. Vivian returns almost at once with a knife an slashes the rope from Marlowe's feet. Dropping the knife, she helps him get up -- he's not too steady on his legs. They cross the room together, Vivian with her arm around Marlowe. The handcuffs glittering on Marlowe's wrists.  162. 140. From outside comes the SOUND of a car skidding to a stop. Mona Mars appears in the doorway, holding a gun.
(quietly, without menace) Eddie is here -- I think you'd better wait.

opening, playing idly with the roll of coins. The CAMERA PULLS BACK -- we are still in the living room. Marlowe is sitting on the couch, Vivian beside him -- his hands are still cuffed behind him, but his feet are free. Canino leans unobtrusively against the wall -- near Marlowe. Eddie Mars holds center stage, moving like a lio keyed up for the kill. Mona Mars, the gun forgotten in he hand, sits in the b.g., watching. Her face is still, intent.
(quietly) Eddie -- this is where I get off.
You bought a ticket for the whole run, Countess -- destination unknown. Keep your mouth out of this. (to Marlowe) You're making it tough for me, soldier.
Not me, Eddie. Murder. Murder can make things tough for anybody. You keep tripping over it, all the time.
(contemptuously) Murder! I haven't killed anybody.

Not personally, maybe -- but your hand is behind Canino's, aiming the gun -- or pouring the cyanide into Harry Jones' glass. (as Mars gives him a startled look) Yeah -- I was there, in the next room. Canino had a gun and I didn't, so all I could do was watch... I kind of liked Harry Jones.  141.
You kind of like too many people, soldier.
Eddie -- what does he mean? What's happened? Who was Harry Jones?
